content.text: On Fig. 1.1, measure the length \(D\)
Using your value of \(D\), calculate the average diameter \(d_{1}\) of **one** marble
Suggest why it is more accurate, when using a ruler, to measure \(D\) for **five** marbles rather than measure the diameter of a single marble
Fig. 1.2 shows two wooden blocks and one of the marbles
Describe how the student uses the two blocks and the marble to determine a new accurate value for the diameter of a marble
Draw a diagram to show the arrangement
Describe clearly how the student ensures that the value for the diameter of a marble is as accurate as possible
The student uses the top pan balance as shown in Fig. 1.3 to measure the mass of the five marbles
He measures the mass \(M_0\) of a beaker without the marbles and then measures the mass \(M_5\) of the same beaker containing the marbles
Record the values of \(M_0\) and \(M_5\) as shown on the top pan balance in Fig. 1.3

He records the reading \(V_{1}\) of the water level in the measuring cylinder

Experiment A

She records the temperature of the water in the beaker every 30 s
Her readings for Experiment A are shown in Table 2.1

On Fig. 3.1, draw a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference (p.d.) across length \(l\) of the resistance wire
The student connects the crocodile clip to a length \(l = 20.0 \text{cm}\) of the resistance wire. He measures the value of potential difference \(V\) and current \(I\) for the resistance wire
Fig. 3.3

The student repeats the process for lengths \(l = 40.0 \text{cm}\), \(l = 60.0 \text{cm}\), \(l = 80.0 \text{cm}\) and \(l = 100.0 \text{cm}\) of the resistance wire in turn
His results are shown in Table 3.1

Draw the straight line of best fit

A student investigates the motion of a ball through the air
Plan an experiment which will enable him to investigate how the range of the ball depends on the angle at which it is launched
The range is the horizontal distance that the ball travels after leaving the end of the channel shown in Fig. 4.1 and before hitting the ground
The apparatus available includes:
â¢ a flexible channel, as shown in Fig. 4.1, which can be bent at different angles
â¢ a selection of balls, each of different diameter and mass

state the key variables to keep constant
